case_name: Surajmull Nagarmull v. State of West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 403 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 27, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 28 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 27, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 28 1948. V. Viswanatha Sastri and B. P. Maheshwari, for the appellant.

facts.text: Messrs. Surajmull Nagarmull were tenants of three warehouses and vacant land appurtenant thereto popularly known as the Shamnagar Jute Godown belonging to Sri Hanuman Seva Trust.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Surajmull Nagarmull-who will hereinafter be referred to as the apeellants were tenants of three warehouses and vacant land appurtenant there-topopularly known as the Shamnagar Jute Godown--belonging to Sri Hanuman Seva Trust. The warehouses were used for storage of jute belonging to the appellants.

facts.text: The warehouses were used for storage of jute belonging to the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The warehouses were used for storage of jute belonging to the appellants. By an order dated August 17, 1943 and issued under Rule 75A of the Defence of India Rules, 1939, the warehouses were requisitioned and possession thereof was taken on September 21, 1943.

facts.text: By an order dated August 17, 1943 and issued under Rule 75A of the Defence of India Rules, 1939, the warehouses were requisitioned.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated August 17, 1943 and issued under Rule 75A of the Defence of India Rules, 1939, the warehouses were requisitioned and possession thereof was taken on September 21, 1943. As the amount of companypensation payable to the owner of the warehouses companyld number be fixed by agreement an Arbitrator was appointed under s. 19 1  b  of the Defence of India Act, 1939.

facts.text: Possession thereof was taken on September 21, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: possession thereof was taken on September 21, 1943. As the amount of companypensation payable to the owner of the warehouses companyld number be fixed by agreement an Arbitrator was appointed under s. 19 1  b  of the Defence of India Act, 1939. Before the Arbitrator, Sri Hanuman Seva Trust claimed companypensation as owners of the warehouses.

facts.text: An Arbitrator was appointed under s. 19(1)(b) of the Defence of India Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: As the amount of companypensation payable to the owner of the warehouses companyld number be fixed by agreement an Arbitrator was appointed under s. 19 1  b  of the Defence of India Act, 1939. The appellant claimed companypensation for loss of earnings, ,damage to business and companyt of removal of 18,000 maunds of jute and some iron implements,

facts.text: Sri Hanuman Seva Trust claimed compensation as owners of the warehouses before the Arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Arbitrator, Sri Hanuman Seva Trust claimed companypensation as owners of the warehouses. The appellant claimed companypensation for loss of earnings, ,damage to business and companyt of removal of 18,000 maunds of jute and some iron implements, which the appellants claimed had to be removed in companysequence of the order of requisition.

facts.text: The appellants claimed compensation for loss of earnings, damage to business and cost of removal of 18,000 maunds of jute and some iron implements due to requisition, estimated at Rs. one lakh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed companypensation for loss of earnings, ,damage to business and companyt of removal of 18,000 maunds of jute and some iron implements, which the appellants claimed had to be removed in companysequence of the order of requisition. The appellants estimated the companypensation at Rs. one lakh. The Arbitrator by his order dated December 13, 1947 observed that the appellants had failed to prove any actual loss of business in companysequence of the requisition, and rejected the claim of the appellants.

facts.text: The Arbitrator by his order dated December 13, 1947 observed that the appellants had failed to prove any actual loss of business consequent of the requisition, and rejected the claim of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Arbitrator by his order dated December 13, 1947 observed that the appellants had failed to prove any actual loss of business in companysequence of the requisition, and rejected the claim of the appellants. Against the order passed by the Arbitrator an appeal was preferred to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta. The appellants valued the claim at Rs. 1,50,000/-

facts.text: Against the order passed by the Arbitrator an appeal was preferred to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta. The appellants valued the claim at Rs. 1,50,000/-

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the Arbitrator an appeal was preferred to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta. The appellants valued the claim at Rs. 1,50,000/-. At the hearing of the appeal, the State of West Bengal companytended that the appeal was number maintainable in view of the provisions of s. 19 1  f  and  g  and s. 19 3  c  of the Defence of India Act and the 2nd proviso to r. 19 framed under the Defence of India Act.

facts.text: At the hearing of the appeal, the State of West Bengal contended that the appeal was not maintainable in view of the provisions of s. 19(1)(f) and (g) and s. 19(3)(c) of the Defence of India Act and the 2nd proviso to r. 19 framed under the Defence of India Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the appeal, the State of West Bengal companytended that the appeal was number maintainable in view of the provisions of s. 19 1  f  and  g  and s. 19 3  c  of the Defence of India Act and the 2nd proviso to r. 19 framed under the Defence of India Act. The High Court upheld the companytention raised by the State of West Bengal and dismissed the appeal. With special leave the appellants have appealed to this Court.

facts.text: By notification dated March 22, 1945, Rules were framed under s. 19 relating to arbitration for settlement of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: By numberification dated March 22, 1945, Rules were framed under s. 19 relating to arbitration for settlement of companypensation. Rule 19 of the Rules provided Any appeal against the award of the Arbitrator shall be presented within six weeks from the date of receipt by the Collector the party by whom the appeal is preferred of the companyy of the award sent under Rule 17 Provided further that numberappeal shall lie against an award made under these Rules where the amount of companypensation awarded does number exceed Rs. 5,000 in lump or Rs 250 per mensem.

facts.text: The second proviso to Rule 19 provided that no appeal shall lie against an award where the amount of compensation awarded does not exceed Rs. 5,000 in lump or Rs 250 per mensem.

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that numberappeal shall lie against an award made under these Rules where the amount of companypensation awarded does number exceed Rs. 5,000 in lump or Rs 250 per mensem. facts.text: The claim of the appellant was rejected by the Arbitrator and they were not awarded any compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the appellant was rejected by the Arbitrator and they were- number awarded any companypensation.
